title: 2,3,5,7-Tetrahydroxy-1,4-naphthalenedione
text:
2,3,5,7-Tetraahydroxy-1,4-naphthalenedione, also called 2,3,5,7-tetrahydroxynaphthoquinone or spinochrome B, is an <a href="organic%20compound">organic compound</a> with formula , formally derived from <a href="naphthoquinone">1,4-naphthoquinone</a> through the replacement of four <a href="hydrogen">hydrogen</a> atoms by <a href="hydroxyl">hydroxyl</a> (OH) groups.
Spinochrome B occurs naturally as <a href="pigment">pigment</a> in the <a href="Mollusc%20shell">shell</a> and spines of sea urchins such as the Japanese dull red species "aka-uni" ("<a href="Pseudocentrotus%20depressus">Pseudocentrotus depressus</a>"), the greenish-black "murasaki-uni" ("<a href="Heliocidaris%20crassispina">Heliocidaris crassispina</a>"), and the brown "bafun-uni" ("<a href="Strongylocentrotus%20pulcherrimus">Strongylocentrotus pulcherrimus</a>"). It is soluble in <a href="methanol">methanol</a> and crystallizes as bright red needles that <a href="Sublimation%20%28phase%20transition%29">sublime</a> above 200 °C.
The compound gives a greenish yellow solution when treated with <a href="sodium%20hydroxide">sodium hydroxide</a>, a green solution with <a href="iron%20%28III%29%20chloride">ferric chloride</a>, and a green precipitate with <a href="lead%20acetate">lead acetate</a>. It forms a fourfold <a href="acetate">acetate</a> <a href="ester">ester</a>, ()4, that crystallizes from <a href="methanol">methanol</a> as yellow needles that melt at 157 °C.
